content: Which ancient civilization built the Great Pyramid of Giza, the Sphinx, and developed a system of writing called hieroglyphics?

The ancient civilization that built the Great Pyramid of Giza, the Sphinx, and developed a system of writing called hieroglyphics is the Ancient Egyptians. The Great Pyramid of Giza, also known as the Pyramid of Khufu or Cheops, is one of the Seven Wonders of the Ancient World and was constructed around 2560 BCE during the Fourth Dynasty of the Old Kingdom. The Sphinx, with its lion's body and human head, is believed to have been built during the reign of Pharaoh Khafre, who also commissioned the second-largest pyramid at Giza.

Hieroglyphics is a formal writing system used by the ancient Egyptians, consisting of intricate symbols and pictures that represented sounds, words, or concepts. This script was used for religious texts, monumental inscriptions, and important documents. The decipherment of hieroglyphics was made possible by the Rosetta Stone, discovered in 1799, which featured the same text in three scripts: ancient Greek, Demotic, and hieroglyphics. French scholar Jean-François Champollion used this trilingual inscription to decode the hieroglyphic script in the early 19th century, opening up a wealth of knowledge about ancient Egyptian civilization.

Ancient Egypt was renowned for its architectural marvels, complex religious beliefs, and advancements in fields such as mathematics, astronomy, and medicine. The civilization thrived along the Nile River for thousands of years, leaving behind a rich cultural heritage that continues to fascinate people around the world.
